medical_history.chief_complaint: Acute psychosis 52 days after gastric bypass surgery
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: Mr. A developed psychotic symptoms, including auditory and visual hallucinations, 52 days after undergoing laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery. He had experiences of feeling 'weird', becoming loud, sleepless, argumentative, and engaged in altercations on a cruise ship. His symptoms initially were attributed to a transdermal scopolamine patch that he used for nausea.
medical_history.past_medical_history: Diagnosed with ocular myasthenia gravis three years prior, underwent thymectomy, and was symptom-free thereafter. No history of substance abuse or psychiatric illness.
medical_history.family_history: No family history of psychiatric illness.
medical_history.social_history: Mr. A was a college graduate working in hotel/restaurant management, recently singing karaoke professionally on weekends. He lived with his wife and two children, and had been the primary caregiver for them during the weekdays.
